items.message: High river levels today may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 21 January 2026. This information is correct as of 15:30 on Wednesday 21 January 2026. The causeway at Welney has approximately 30cm of water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 26cm of water on the road. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. There are currently no issues on Earith causeway. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 08:00 on Thursday 22 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
River levels remain high in the Rivers Yeo and Parrett following Tuesday’s rain.

The drain level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is currently 7.22m and rising. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m, and the road from Muchelney to Draycott, Law Lane, above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels.

Further rain and unsettled conditions are forecast for the coming days, and this is expected to keep river levels high. The River Parrett is currently bank-full and spillways are running. We will open the Parrett Relief Channel and commence pumping activities as soon as river levels drop enough to allow this.

We continue to monitor the situation closely. Please avoid low lying paths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 22 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high following Tuesday's rain, and this may lead to flooding on Wednesday and overnight into Thursday as unsettled conditions continue. 

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.52m. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.39m and rising. Cutts Road floods when this level is above 5.75m, and New Road when the level is above 6.18m. Please refer to the Somerset Council website for information on road closures in the area. 

Further rain, possibly heavy, is forecast for the remainder of Wednesday and Thursday, and water levels are likely to remain high. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels closely and Field Teams are out clearing trash screens and checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and paths near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 1pm on 22nd January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message:
Rising groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. 
Flooding is expected from 19th January 2026 onwards. 
Groundwater levels in West Dorset remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Winterbourne Abbas, Winterbourne Steepleton, Martinstown, Winterbourne Monkton, Winterbourne Herringston and Winterbourne Came. The groundwater level at the Kingston Russell borehole has risen to 116.56m, and is expected to rise further over the next few days. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected. Roads may be damaged by floodwater. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts . 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 26 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Brue (upper) from Bruton Dam to Lovington
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. 
Further rainfall is forecast but no further flooding is expected. THIS FLOOD WARNING WAS ISSUED IN ERROR. NO ACTION IS REQUIRED. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. THIS FLOOD WARNING WAS ISSUED IN ERROR. NO ACTION REQUIRED.
